summary: Evelio Duque Miyar was a Cuban anti-communist who had past interactions with the CIA. The CIA provided assistance to him at one point but later terminated the relationship due to disagreements over operational control. In the early 1960s, he may have been involved in Cuban operations in the Miami area. In 1978, he opened a confectionery store across from the consulate in Guayaquil, Ecuador. There were concerns about his potential connections to drug trafficking and exile group affiliations. The documents suggest the CIA was interested in tracing his activities and connections, particularly regarding anti-Castro activities.
significance: Based on the provided documents, Evelio Duque Miyar's significance in the JFK assassination context is not explicitly stated. The documents focus on his anti-communist activities, past CIA connections, and potential involvement in other activities. Further research would be needed to determine if he had any direct or indirect relevance to the JFK assassination.
